page.title: 02The Kinross Basin.
page.content: The Kinross Basin is hollowed out of Old Red{lavas and sandstones,}and,in the Lomond-Benarty-Cleish Hills,of Carboniferous sediments.The Midland Valley{dolerite sill}caps these hills, making them more dominant than the Ochil Hills.Millions of years of {erosion}created a valley system drained eastwards by the Devon.Since {glaciation}only small streams drain into the Kinross Basin from the Ochils.Deglaciation of the last ice sheet around 13,000 years ago,involved {outwash}pouring eastwards into the area creating kames and kettleholes. The largest kettlehole is Loch Leven, with kames breaking its surface as islands.
